Award.AwardTitle: UNH/IAM Workshop on Advancing Wall-Turbulence Model Development and Implementation, University of New Hampshire

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal ID: 1558366
PI: Klewicki, Joseph

The proposal seeks funds to partially cover expenses related to the organization of the workshop entitled ?UNH/IAM Workshop on Advancing Wall-Turbulence Model Development and Implementation?, to be held at the campus of the University of New Hampshire, in November 19-20, 2015.
While turbulence is an old problem in engineering, it is one of the most important practical problems in both the industry and the environment, since the majority of flows around us are turbulent (e.g., atmospheric boundary layer, flows in oceans, in chemical processes, etc). During the past decade, however, there have been transformational advances in experimentation and simulation, and these have led to the capacity to characterize the temporal and spatial structure of turbulent boundary layers at unprecedented levels of detail. These advances can further lead to our ability to control turbulence with profound impact in energy consumption, pollutant generation and dispersion, transportation and climate change.
The focus of the workshop will be on areas that are very research active, including i) Exact Coherent Structures; ii) Data Informed Sparse Representations; iii) Quasi-linearized Models, and iv) Asymptotically Reduced PDE Models. A goal of the workshop is to advance a deeper understanding of the details of how the various modeling strategies developed recently in these areas are pragmatically implemented. It would provide ample opportunities for lengthy and open discussions that will usefully facilitate the understanding by the non-experts on how their experiment and/or computation based research might usefully connect to model development and implementation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The turbulent flow near a solid surface is of high scientific and technological importance. This importance stems from the fact that the motions within these turbulent wall-flows determine the rates at which the surface-normal transport of quantities such as heat, mass and momentum occurs.  Unfortunately, the high Reynolds number condition for turbulent wall-flows is both difficult to study experimentally, and is currently inaccessible by large scale computations, and will be for many years to come. For this reason, high fidelity models that efficiently capture the essential dynamics of high Reynolds number wall-flows flows provide an attractive means of addressing the need to continue to improve our capacity to predict and understand these flows.

Relevant to this need, research pertaining to the instantaneous dynamics, statistical structure, and scaling behaviors of turbulent wall-flows has experienced a resurgence over the past two decades. This circumstance stems from an ever-increasing pace of new findings resulting from rapid advances in experimental and computational methods. As might be anticipated, this poses new opportunities,and the resulting improved understanding of the physics is increasingly being leveraged by an emergent suite of analytical techniques that hold potential pertinent to theconstruction of predictive models of turbulent wall-flow dynamics at high Reynolds
number. A distinctive trait of these models is that they retain a much firmer grounding in the underlying Navier-Stokes equations (an expression of Newton’s second law) than do the previous generation of models. Recognizing the potential of these new developments, in November 2013 the Integrated Applied Mathematics (IAM) Program at the University of New Hampshire (UNH) hosted (via NSF support) a workshop entitled “High Reynolds Number Boundary Layer Turbulence: Integrating Descriptions of Statistical Structure, Scaling and Dynamical Evolution”. The stated purpose of this workshop was to advance turbulent boundary layer model development by bringing together world-leading experimental and computational practitioners with applied mathematicians who are working on model development and associated analysis methods. Since the first UNH workshop, the Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics (IPAM) at UCLA held a long program on “The Mathematics of Turbulence.” This was in the fall of 2014. The Engineering Applications portion of the IPAM program complemented the aims of the UNH workshop by continuing many of the relevant themes. It also revealed that considerable benefits could be derived from all interested parties through the acquisition of a more detailed understanding of how the variety of analysis methods are devised and implemented in practice.

Building upon the IPAM and first UNH/IAM workshop, the primary purpose of the second UNH/IAMworkshop, “UNH/IAMWorkshop on AdvancingWall Turbulence Model Development and Implementation,” was to provide a greater commonality of understanding regarding the actual implementation of the predominant analysis methodologies. As such, this workshop, which was held at UNH in November 2015, had a smaller participant list, but was considerably more interactive in its design and execution.

The workshop was held on the campus of the University of New Hampshire from Thursday November 19, 2015 to Friday November 20, 2015. This venue and dates were chosen to be convenient for the large number of invitees who also attended the APS-DFD conference in Boston immediately after the workshop. Given the priorities noted above, the 2015 workshop focused on areas of especially active research into model development and analysis, namely:
1. Exact Coherent Structures
2. Data Informed Sparse Representations
3. Quasi-linearized Models, and
4. Asymptotically Reduced PDE Models

The two day program was composed of four sessions, each focusing on one of the above topics. Each session began with an extended (50 minute) introductory presentation consisting of a tutorial style lecture. Here, a leading researcher in the given area provided both an overview of the method, and a detailed accounting of the pragmatic elements that need to be considered when implementing the given method. The target for these lectures was at the level of non-expert, and thus were specifically designed to encourage questions and discussion amongst the non applied mathematicians on the elements of the particular modeling approach, and its practical implementation. The remaining two talks in each session (25 minutes each) provided more detailed examples of how a variant of the given method was applied to a particular research problem. These highlighted how the method was tailored for the given application.

Leading experts were selected to moderate the four sessions, Bruno Eckhardt (Phillips-Marburg) Exact Coherent Structures; Beverley McKeon (Caltech) Data Informed Sparse Representations; Javier Jimenez (Madrid) Quasi-linearized Models; Rich Kerswell (Bristol) Asymptotically Reduced PDE Models. The tutorial speakers for the four sessions were: Exact Coherent Structures, John Gibson (New Hampshire), Data Informed Sparse Representations, Maziar Hemati (Minnesota), Quasi-linearized Models, Brad Marston (Brown), Asymptotically Reduced PDE Models, Keith Julien (Colorado). The shorter talks were given by Dennice Gayme (JHU), Brian Farrell (Harvard), Greg Chini (UNH), Edgar Knobloch (Berkeley), Tobias Kreilos (Lausanne), Lennaert van Veen (OIT), Maziar Hemati (UMN), Simon Illingworth (Mel-bourne), Ati Sharma (Southampton).
